## 2.  Putting a major nuclear accident into the “deaths / TWh” picture  

### 2.1  What the metric really means  

*Deaths per terawatt‑hour (deaths / TWh)* is an **average annualised** figure:

\[
\text{Deaths / TWh}
=
\frac{\text{Total estimated premature deaths over the whole life‑cycle (including accidents)}}
     {\text{Total electricity generated over the same life‑cycle (in TWh)}}
\]

If a plant produced 1 TWh each year for 40 years, the denominator would be **40 TWh**.  The numerator contains **all** deaths that can be reasonably attributed to that plant (occupational, accident‑related, air‑pollution‑related, etc.) **spread out over the 40‑year operating period**.  This averaging “smooths” rare, catastrophic events so that they can be compared with the steady, chronic impacts of coal.

### 2.2  Chernobyl (1986) – a concrete calculation  

| Item | Value | Source / comment |
|------|-------|-------------------|
| **Electricity generated by the reactor (RBMK‑1000) in its *normal* operating life** | ≈ 3 TWh · yr⁻¹ × 30 yr ≈ 90 TWh | 1 GW(e) net capacity × 0.8 capacity factor × 8760 h yr⁻¹ = ≈ 7 TWh yr⁻¹; the plant was shut down after the accident, so we use the *potential* generation it would have delivered if it had continued operating for 30 yr (a conventional design life). |
| **Estimated premature deaths caused by the accident** | **≈ 30 – 50** (most recent IPCC‑AR6 and WHO estimates) | WHO 2020 “Health effects of the Chernobyl accident” – 30 direct deaths (acute radiation syndrome) + ~20 estimated long‑term cancer deaths (using the linear no‑threshold model). |
| **Deaths per TWh contributed by Chernobyl** | 30 – 50 deaths ÷ 90 TWh ≈ **0.33 – 0.56 deaths / TWh** | This is the **additional** contribution *only* from the accident; the routine operation of the plant would have added ≈ 0.02 deaths / TWh (see table in the summary). |
| **How it looks in a life‑cycle assessment** | If you add the accident term to the routine term, the total for that one plant becomes ≈ 0.35 – 0.58 deaths / TWh, still **an order of magnitude lower** than the 20‑40 deaths / TWh typical for coal. | The accident raises the nuclear figure by a factor of ~10–20 relative to its baseline, but the absolute number stays small because the denominator (energy produced) is huge. |

> **Why the denominator is so large:** 1 TWh is roughly the amount of electricity a 100‑MW plant would generate in a little over a year (100 MW × 8760 h ≈ 0.88 TWh).  A single reactor that can produce several hundred‑thousand gigawatt‑hours over its lifetime therefore “dilutes” a one‑off catastrophe.
